Title: Bright light at night alters the perception of daylength in Indian weaver bird (Ploceus philippinus)
Authors: Jayant Kumar, Shalie Malik, Sanjay Kumar Bhardwaj, Sangeeta Rani
Venue: Journal of Experimental Zoology Part A Ecological and Integrative Physiology
Supporting quotes for "Location": - "The present study was done on Indian weaver bird (Ploceus philippinus), commonly known as baya. It is a photoperiodic, long day breeding sparrow-sized finch that belongs to the family Ploceidae. These birds are strictly diurnal and roost in reed-beds near water bodies away from human settlements. However, due to increasing urbanization and shrinkage of agricultural landscape of India, the weaver birds are now exposed to nights brighter than before."
Reasoning for "Location":
The location of the study is not explicitly stated in the paper. However, based on the information provided, we can infer that the study was conducted in India:
"The present study was done on Indian weaver bird (Ploceus philippinus), commonly known as baya. It is a photoperiodic, long day breeding sparrow-sized finch that belongs to the family Ploceidae. These birds are strictly diurnal and roost in reed-beds near water bodies away from human settlements. However, due to increasing urbanization and shrinkage of agricultural landscape of India, the weaver birds are now exposed to nights brighter than before."
The paper mentions that the study was conducted on the Indian weaver bird, which is native to India. Additionally, the paper discusses the impact of urbanization and industrialization in India on the weaver birds, further suggesting that the study was conducted in India.
